title: Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Three Hot International Issues
summary: The Secretary of State discusses the status of Russia and Ukraine, China and Taiwan, and Iran negotiations. Nations the world over have been taking the Biden administration's measure in its first year. The massing of Russian troops at Ukraine's border and an increasingly assertive China are just two of the international challenges facing the White House. America's top diplomat, Secretary of State Antony Blinken, sat down at the WSJ CEO Council Summit for a discussion about U.S. diplomacy with Thorold Barker, editor, Europe, Middle East and Africa, for The Wall Street Journal. Edited excerpts follow.

summary: Gary Gensler also discusses possible new rules around human-capital disclosures. The Securities and Exchange Commission has a lot to tackle.

title: The Real Cost of Biden's Spending Plan
summary: CBO comes clean on the price tag if the programs are made permanent.. President Biden's tax and entitlement plan received what should be a pair of knockout punches late last week. The report of surging inflation has been well covered. But the media have largely ignored the second blow-the real cost of the plan if honestly scored. Allow us to complete the record.

title: Randi Weingarten Says Pass the SALT
summary: The teachers union chief wants to give millionaires a tax break.. With battles over school closures, vaccine mandates and curricula, you might think the president of the American Federation of Teachers has enough on her plate. But Randi Weingarten is now lobbying hard for a tax break whose benefits would go mostly to the wealthy. She wants Democrats to restore the deduction for state and local taxes in their giant tax and spending bill.

title: Almost Anybody Can Now Vote in New York
summary: Democrats on the City Council give 800,000 noncitizens the franchise, as others dissent.. The New York City Council approved a bill last week to let about 800,000 noncitizens vote in local elections, and Mayor Bill de Blasio has said he won't veto it. The measure passed 33-14, over some strong dissents, including from Democrats.

title: Republicans Can Embrace Much of Biden's Anticorruption Plan
summary: The president hasn't been tough enough on Russia and China, but in general terms his strategy is good.. Kleptocracy deprives the developing world of trillions of dollars each year, fueling poverty and conflict while entrenching powerful regimes in China, Russia, Iran and Venezuela. From the failure in Afghanistan to the unopposed expansion of Beijing's Belt and Road Initiative, corruption plays a pervasive role in undermining U.S. foreign policy and national security.

title: The Unconstitutional Convictions You Don't Know About
summary: Though right to a jury trial is enshrined in the Bill of Rights and Constitution, it's hardly ever enforced.. Four recent trials have left Americans divided and skeptical over whether our criminal-justice system actually produces just outcomes. The conviction of three men for the murder of Ahmaud Arbery, the acquittal of Kyle Rittenhouse, the conviction of Jussie Smollett for falsely reporting a hate crime, and the trial of Elizabeth Holmes for allegedly lying to investors have played out in much different ways, with legitimately controversial outcomes in the first three cases. But these prosecutions share one favorable aspect: All were decided by juries, a development that regrettably has become highly unusual in our court system.

title: School Choice Saves Money and Helps Kids
summary: Evidence builds, as political momentum grows in the states.. The momentum toward educational choice is undeniable. This year has seen unprecedented state-level expansion of educational opportunities for millions of families across the country, with 18 states passing legislation to introduce or expand educational choice programs-a trend that's primed to continue through the 2022 election cycle. The recent electoral success of choice supporters in Virginia and New Jersey-traditional strongholds for special-interest groups that strongly oppose choice-coupled with school-board elections driven by parents wanting a voice in their kids' classrooms, is emboldening states to expand educational options.

title: Chile's High-Stakes Election
summary: The country's left has taken a radical turn and wants to rewrite the constitution.. The stakes are high in Chile's Dec. 19 runoff presidential election pitting the free-market former Congressman José Antonio Kast against socialist Congressman Gabriel Boric.

title: 'George Hearst' Review: A Head for Metals
summary: At first nobody believed the ore Hearst brought back was worth anything. Turns out it was one of the earliest hauls from the Comstock Lode.. George Hearst was famous for discovering metals-copper, silver, gold-but he liked any mineral he could pull out of the earth. New Year's Eve 1889 found him far from his San Francisco home, in West Virginia's coal country. "We found the coal veins all right," said Hearst's traveling companion, T.J. Clunie, a young California state senator. "The samples were fine, the price was low, and I expected to see Hearst snap at the offer." But Hearst was hesitant. "I don't like to buy a pig in a poke," he said. "We had better crawl up and see that coal for ourselves before we discuss the price." That meant scaling a 3,000-foot hill.

title: Ted Lasso's Cultural References, Decrypted
summary: Arcane cultural references are sprinkled throughout the hot TV show. For those who didn't catch them, or understand them, we're here to help.. Streamed on Apple TV+, the show won seven Primetime Emmy Awards in September, including one for outstanding comedy series and another for lead actor in a comedy role, with Jason Sudeikis playing the title character.

title: Biden Aims to Win Pivotal Democrat's Support for $2 Trillion Spending Plan

WASHINGTON-President Biden this week will lobby Sen. Joe Manchin, the centrist West Virginia Democrat, in an attempt to lock in a deal on a roughly $2 trillion social-policy and climate bill that Democrats hope to finish by Christmas.

title: Alibaba Fires Female Employee Who Accused Then-Supervisor of Sexual Assault

HONG KONG- Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. has fired a female employee who accused her then-supervisor of molestation and rape during a business trip earlier this year, according to the woman and her lawyer, refocusing attention on a sexual-assault case that sent ripples through China's tech sector.

title: Newsom Uses Texas Abortion Law as Gun Suit Model

title: Deadly Tornadoes That Ravaged Six States Tied to Weird Weather Patterns
summary: Scientists said the twisters were spawned by unusual heat and humidity and were reluctant to blame them on climate change. The deadly tornadoes that ripped through six states in as many hours on Friday night were spawned by unusually hot, humid weather at a time of year when twisters are rare, federal weather scientists said.

title: How America Can Keep Its Lead in Technology
summary: Research isolated from manufacturing isn't effective. Integrated R&D is China's decisive advantage.. Graham Allison and Eric Schmidt argue forcefully for a national effort to preserve America's technological leadership against a rising China ("China Will Soon Lead the U.S. in Tech," op-ed, Dec. 8). But we need stronger medicine than they prescribe to "organize a national response analogous to the mobilization . . . that won World War II."

title: The Downward Spiral of America's Second City
summary: No amount of Build Back Better funds will solve the systemic problems.. Those of us who came of age in Chicago loved the city for all reasons. From Daniel Burnham to the Daleys, Robert McCormick and all the industrial magnates who line the front of the Merchandise Mart, Chicago had much to admire. The architecture, the teams, the markets, the melting-pot culture. From the excesses of politics to the steady hand of industry, it was always the city that worked.

title: Women's Tennis Deserves Our Support After Standing Up to China
summary: Who will step up to fund WTA tournaments in the months and years ahead?. Regarding your editorial "Advantage, Women's Tennis Association" (Dec. 2): I remember as a young boy hearing Flip Wilson's comic line, "the devil made me do it," to explain his missteps. Even as kids, we knew that the devil excuse was lame and inexcusable. Yet I'm reminded of the line whenever I read about the NBA's or BlackRock's refusals to challenge China's abuses of human rights. These entities must know that they are dealing with a devilish regime, but they remain silent and engaged for the sake of revenues.

title: A Research Grant Is Only the Beginning for a New Drug
summary: It is a tiny fraction of the investment required to bring a new therapy to market.. Amy Dockser Marcus's review of "The Genome Defense" by Jorge Contreras (Bookshelf, Dec. 8) cites his view that government grants at research universities justify federal price intervention if an invention results and is commercialized by a biotech or pharmaceutical company. This conveniently ignores that such government funding is a tiny fraction of the investment required to bring a new therapy to market.

title: One-Upping John D. Rockefeller
summary: A dime in 1920s money still can't top a twenty today.. Kudos to Allan Ripp for gratuitously, unexpectedly and discreetly handing $20 bills to myriad "people going about their jobs with no expectations of being personally thanked" ("How I Reached the Tipping Point," op-ed, Dec. 9). Mr. Ripp's practice recalls that of multimillionaire John D. Rockefeller, the richest man in the world for some time, known for bestowing a dime on many people he came across.

title: Old Wisdom for Today's Markets
summary: My advice is to figure out in which direction the consensus is wrong. I love Wall Street adages-find all 30-that help explain today's crazy markets. One that keeps popping into my head lately is "bulls make money, bears make money, but pigs get slaughtered." I've called this market bubblicious, and markets still push relentlessly higher. My mentor, the famed investor Barton Biggs, explained, "A bull market is like sex. It feels best just before it ends." And now as coronavirus variants come and go, we see 500-point yo-yo swings. Be warned, no one rings a bell at the top of markets.

title: The Fed Is the Main Inflation Culprit

With several strokes of the pen, regulators wiped out hundred of billions of dollars of equity value, and imposed new and more restrictive regulations on a range of sectors, from internet finance to education.

title: Verstappen Beats Hamilton to Win Formula One Title

But he was able to turn the months of lockdown and virtual work into one of the most creative times in his life. And the proof is in the remarkable response to his most recent album, "We Are," released in March, and the recognition he recently received from his peers: 11 Grammy nominations.
